questions.question_text: What is the result of a segmentation criteria filtering on City | Is Equal To | 'San José'?

choices.C: Cities only containing 'San José' or 'San Jose'
choices.A: Cities containing 'San Jose', ’San José', 'san josé, or 'san jose'
choices.B: Cities only containing 'San José or 'san josé'
choices.D: Cities only containing 'San Jose' or 'san jose'

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It is B. Values are case-insensitive but matches only with "é" with an accent.

Selected Answer: B
Tested it on playground for Jack and Jáck; doesnt give same count of segment population.

Selected Answer: B
The value against which the attribute value is compared to determines whether it satisfies the condition. Queries honor exact matching on special characters and accents and aren’t case-sensitive. For example, querying on City | Is Equal To | Canon City doesn’t find the city Cañon City. A query on City | Is Equal To | Canon City finds canon city. Also, queries honor exact matching on types.

Selected Answer: D
According to the Data Cloud documentation, the Is Equal To operator is case-insensitive, meaning it matches values regardless of capitalization. Therefore, the segmentation criteria filtering on City | Is Equal To | 'San Jose' will include cities that contain either 'San Jose' or 'san jose'.

Selected Answer: B
Queries honor exact matching on special characters and accents and aren’t case-sensitive.

Selected Answer: B
When using an "Is Equal To" filter with a segmentation criteria, the system will only match entries that exactly match the specified value

Selected Answer: A
A. Cities containing 'San Jose', ’San José', 'san josé, or 'san jose'

Selected Answer: B
san jose won't be selected

Salesforce Help article: https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.c360_a_segment_canvas_interface.htm&type=5
Value Field
The value against which the attribute value is compared to determines whether it satisfies the condition. Queries honor exact matching on special characters and accents and aren’t case-sensitive. For example, querying on City | Is Equal To | Canon City doesn’t find the city Cañon City. A query on City | Is Equal To | Canon City finds canon city. Also, queries honor exact matching on types. For example, if the field type is a string for "Purchase Order Number", querying on Purchase order number | Is Equal To | 0852 finds a Purchase Order Number that’s equal to 0852. It doesn't find the purchase order number 852, which has no leading zero, or “0852” with quotation marks.

Selected Answer: A
Cities containing 'San Jose', ’San José', 'san josé, or 'san jose'
A. Cities containing 'San Jose', ’San José', 'san josé, or 'san jose'

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
I believe the answer is A
Here's why:
This trailhead module on Creating Segments has a Values section that says "Values are pretty straightforward. They are the thing you want your filter to find. And there’s good news! Values are not case sensitive."

choices.C: Data Cloud for Marketing Data Aware Specialist

discussion.content:

Answer is C

Selected Answer: C
key here is that they want the user to validate the mapping. Data Cloud User doesn't have access to it

Selected Answer: C
A "Data Cloud User" cannot changes anything. Only can check the data.

Correct answer should be C
This permission set is specifically designed for users who need to interact with data in a more detailed manner than a general user. It includes the capabilities to review, validate, and modify data, matching the described needs without the broader administrative permissions.

Data Cloud User (Option D) can NOT be correct: 
This permission set typically provides basic access to Data Cloud features. It might allow reviewing data but often does not include permissions to make changes or validate the data modeling, which is required in this case.

questions.question_text:
A new user of Data Cloud only needs to be able to review individual rows of ingested data and validate that it has been modeled successfully to its linked data model object. The user will also need to make changes if required.
What is the minimum permission set needed to accommodate this use case?

discussion.content:

questions.question_text:
Northern Trail Outfitters wants to be able to calculate each customer's lifetime value (LTV) but also create breakdowns of the revenue sourced by website, mobile app, and retail channels.

What should a consultant use to address this use case in Data Cloud?

choices.C: Delete the data from the incoming data stream and perform a full refresh.
choices.B: Use Data Explorer to locate and manually remove the Individual.
choices.D: Add the Individual ID to a headerless file and use the delete from file functionality.
choices.A: Use the Consent API to suppress processing and delete the individual and related records from source data streams.

discussion.content: All good. AD make sense after all!
I do not believe that A is correct here. My answers here would be B and D.

questions.question_text:
Cloud Kicks received a Request to be Forgotten by a customer.

In which two ways should a consultant use Data Cloud to honor this request? (Choose two.)

A customer is trying to activate data from Data Cloud to an Amazon S3 Cloud File Storage Bucket.
Which authentication type should the consultant recommend to connect to the S3 bucket from Data Cloud?

discussion.content:
D. Use an S3 Access Key and Secret Key. 

Access keys ensure granular (specifically what's required) access policies in AWS. e.g., PUT, DELETE only limited to certain S3 folder etc.

choices.C: Use an S3 Encrypted Username and Password.
choices.B: Use an S3 Private Key Certificate.
choices.D: Use an S3 Access Key and Secret Key.
choices.A: Use a JWT Token generated on S3.
